Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Story: I glanced out the salon window just in time to see my stepbrother, Jamie, dragging his skateboard toward the old, cracked ramp across the street. My heart skipped—he’d been talking about trying that new trick for weeks, and I’d promised our parents I’d keep an eye on him. But right now, I was in the middle of a colour appointment with a new client, Mrs. Patel, who was frowning at her reflection. “It’s a bit warmer than I expected,” she said, her voice tight. I could feel her disappointment, and I knew I needed to reassure her, maybe offer a toner or a redo. But my mind kept darting to Jamie, picturing him wobbling at the top of that ramp, no helmet in sight. I felt torn in two—my hands wanted to reach for the colour chart, but my eyes kept flicking to the window, watching Jamie’s every move. I could almost hear my parents’ voices: “Look out for him, please.” But Mrs. Patel was waiting for my answer, her trust in my hands. My chest tightened as I tried to figure out who needed me more in this moment.
